knife.lazy.lazyknife — lazily evaluated knife¶

class knife.lazy.lazyknife(*things, **kw)[source]¶

lazy knife

all()¶

Discover if worker() returns True for everything within an iterable (or if the iterable is empty).

>>> __(2, 4, 6, 8).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0).all().fetch()
True
any()¶

Discover if worker() returns True for anything within an iterable (or if the iterable is empty).

>>> __(1, 4, 5, 9).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0).any().fetch()
True
append(*things)¶

Insert things after other incoming things.

>>> __(3, 4, 5).append(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).peek()
[3, 4, 5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
Parameters:things – incoming things
argmap(merge=False)¶

Feed each thing within an iterable to worker() as wildcard positional arguments .

>>> # default behavior
>>> __((1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)).worker(lambda x, y: x * y).argmap().fetch()
[2, 6, 12]
>>> # merge global positional arguments with iterable arguments
>>> __((1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)).worker(
...   lambda x, y, z, a, b: x * y * z * a * b
...   ).params(7, 8, 9).argmap(merge=True).fetch()
[1008, 3024, 6048]
Parameters:merge (boolean) – merge global positional params() with positional arguments derived from an iterable
as_ascii(errors='strict')¶

Set type caster to byte encode outgoing things with the 'ascii' codec.

>>> __([1], True, r't', b('i'), u('g'), None, (1,)).as_ascii().cast_each().peek()
(b('[1]'), b('True'), b('t'), b('i'), b('g'), b('None'), b('(1,)'))
Parameters:errors (string) – error handling for decoding issues
as_bytes(encoding='utf-8', errors='strict')¶

Set type caster to byte encode outgoing things.

>>> ([1], True, r't', b('i'), u('g'), None, (1,)).as_bytes().cast_each().peek()
(b('[1]'), b('True'), b('t'), b('i'), b('g'), b('None'), b('(1,)'))
Parameters:
  • encoding (string) – Unicode encoding
  • errors (string) – error handling for encoding issues
as_type(wrapper)¶

Assign type caster for outgoing things.

>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).as_type(tuple).peek()
(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
Parameters:wrapper –

an iterable as_type
as_unicode(encoding='utf-8', errors='strict')¶

Set type caster to unicode (str under Python 3) decode outgoing things.

>>> __([1], True, r't', b('i'), u('g'), None, (1,)).as_unicode().cast_each().peek()
(u('[1]'), u('True'), u('t'), u('i'), u('g'), u('None'), u('(1,)'))
Parameters:
  • encoding (string) – Unicode encoding
  • errors (string) – error handling for decoding issues
at(n, default=None)¶

Slice off thing found at iterable index n.

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).at(2).fetch()
3
>>> # return default value if nothing found at index
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).at(10, 11).fetch()
11
Parameters:
  • n (integer) – index of some thing
  • default – default thing returned if nothing is found at n
attributes(*names)¶

Collect attribute values from things within an iterable that matches an attribute name value found in names.

>>> from stuf import stuf
>>> stooge = [
...    stuf(name='moe', age=40),
...    stuf(name='larry', age=50),
...    stuf(name='curly', age=60),
... ]
>>> ___(*stooge).attributes('name').fetch()
['moe', 'larry', 'curly']
>>> # multiple attribute names
>>> __(*stooge).attributes('name', 'age').fetch()
[('moe', 40), ('larry', 50), ('curly', 60)]
>>> # no attributes named 'place'
>>> __(*stooge).attributes('place').fetch()
[]
Parameters:names (string) – attribute names
average()¶

Find average value within an iterable.

>>> __(10, 40, 45).average().fetch()
31.666666666666668
cast_each()¶

Toggle whether each item should be cast to wrapping type or everything.

choice()¶

Randomly slice off one thing from an iterable.

>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).choice().fetch()
3
clear()¶

Clear everything.

combinations(n)¶

Find combinations of every n things within an iterable.

>>> __(40, 50, 60).combinations(2).fetch()
[(40, 50), (40, 60), (50, 60)]
Parameters:n (integer) – length of things to combine from
copy()¶

Duplicate each thing within an iterable.

>>> __([[1, [2, 3]], [4, [5, 6]]]).copy().fetch()
[[1, [2, 3]], [4, [5, 6]]]
count()¶

Count how many times each thing occurs within an iterable.

>>> common = __(11, 3, 5, 11, 7, 3, 5, 11).count().fetch()
>>> # least common thing
>>> common.least_common
7
>>> # most common thing
>>> common.most_common
11
>>> # total count for every thing
>>> common.totals
[(11, 3), (3, 2), (5, 1), (7, 1)])
Returns:tuple of (least common thing, most common thing, [count of everything (a list of tuple pairs of (thing, count))]).
dice(n, fill=None)¶

Slice one iterable into multiple iterables of n things.

>>> ('moe', 'larry', 'curly', 30, 40, 50, True).dice(2, 'x').fetch()
[('moe', 'larry'), ('curly', 30), (40, 50), (True, 'x')]
Parameters:
  • n (integer) – number of things per slice
  • fill – value to pad out incomplete things
difference(symmetric=False)¶

Find differences within a series of iterables.

>>> # default behavior
>>> __([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], [5, 2, 10], [10, 11, 2]).difference().fetch()
[1, 3, 4]
>>> # symmetric difference
>>> __([1, 3, 4, 5], [5, 2, 10], [10, 11, 2]).difference(symmetric=True).fetch()
[1, 3, 4, 11]
Parameters:symmetric (boolean) – use symmetric difference
duality()¶

Divide one iterable into two iterables, the first being everything worker() evaluates as True and the second being everything worker() evaluates as False.

>>> divide = __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0).duality().fetch()
>>> divide.true
[2, 4, 6]
>>> divide.false
[1, 3, 5]
fetch()¶

Return outgoing things (wrapped with the current iterable as_type.

filter(invert=False)¶

Collect each thing within an iterable matched by worker().

>>> # filter for true values
>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0).filter().fetch()
[2, 4, 6]
>>> # filter for false values
>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).worker(lambda x: x % 2 == 0).filter(invert=True).fetch()
[1, 3, 5]
Parameters:invert (boolean) – collect things worker() evaluates as False instead of True
first(n=0)¶

Slice off n things from the starting end of an iterable or just the first thing.

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).first().fetch()
5
>>> # first things from index 0 to 2
__(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).first(2).fetch()
[5, 4]
Parameters:n (integer) – number of things
flatten()¶

Flatten nested things within an iterable down to one (unnested) level.

>>> __([[1, [2], [3, [[4]]]], 'here']).flatten().fetch()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 'here']
group()¶

Group things within an iterable using worker() as the key function.

>>> # default grouping
>>> __(1.3, 2.1, 2.4).group().fetch()
[(1.3, (1.3,)), (2.1, (2.1,)), (2.4, (2.4,))]
>>> from math import floor
>>> # use worker for key function
>>> __(1.3, 2.1, 2.4).worker(floor).group().fetch()
[(1.0, (1.3,)), (2.0, (2.1, 2.4))]
initial()¶

Slice off everything from an iterable except the last thing.

>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).initial().fetch()
[5, 4, 3, 2]
intersection()¶

Find intersections within a series of iterables.

>>> __([1, 2, 3], [101, 2, 1, 10], [2, 1]).intersection().fetch()
[1, 2]
invoke(name)¶

Call method name from each thing within an iterable with the global positional and keyword arguments but take the original thing if the return value of the method call is None.

>>> # invoke list.index()
>>> __([5, 1, 7], [3, 2, 1]).params(1).invoke('index').fetch()
[1, 2]
>>> # invoke list.sort() but return sorted list instead of None
>>> __([5, 1, 7], [3, 2, 1]).invoke('sort').fetch()
[[1, 5, 7], [1, 2, 3]]
Parameters:name (string) – method name
items(*keys)¶

Collect values from things (usually sequences or mappings) within an iterable that match a key value found in keys.

>>> stooge = [
...    dict(name='moe', age=40),
...    dict(name='larry', age=50),
...    dict(name='curly', age=60)
... ]
>>> # get items from mappings like dictionaries, etc...
>>> __(*stooge).items('name').fetch()
['moe', 'larry', 'curly']
>>> __(*stooge).items('name', 'age').fetch()
[('moe', 40), ('larry', 50), ('curly', 60)]
>>> # get items from sequences like lists, tuples, etc...
>>> stooge = [['moe', 40], ['larry', 50], ['curly', 60]]
>>> __(*stooge).items(0).fetch()
['moe', 'larry', 'curly']
>>> __(*stooge).items(1).fetch()
[40, 50, 60])
>>> __(*stooge).items('place').fetch()
[]
Parameters:keys (string) – item keys or indexes
kwargmap(merge=False)¶

Feed each thing within an iterable as a tuple of wildcard positional and keyword arguments to worker().

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(((1, 2), {'a': 2}), ((2, 3), {'a': 2}), ((3, 4), {'a': 2})).worker(test).kwargmap().fetch()
[6, 10, 14]
>>> def test(*args, **kw):
...    return sum(args) * sum(kw.values())
>>> # merging global and iterable derived positional and keyword args
>>> __(((1, 2), {'a': 2}), ((2, 3), {'a': 2}), ((3, 4), {'a': 2})).worker(test).params(
... 1, 2, 3, b=5, w=10, y=13).kwargmap(merge=True).fetch()
[270, 330, 390]
Parameters:merge (boolean) – merge global positional or keyword params() with positional and keyword arguments derived from an iterable into a single tuple of wildcard positional and keyword arguments like (iterable_args + global_args, global_kwargs + iterable_kwargs)
last(n=0)¶

Slice off either n things from the tail end of an iterable or just the last thing.

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).last().fetch()
1
>>> # fetch last two things
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).last(2).fetch()
[2, 1]
Parameters:n (integer) – number of things
map()¶

Feed each thing within an iterable to worker().

>>> __(1, 2, 3).worker(lambda x: x * 3).map().fetch()
[3, 6, 9]
mapping(keys=False, values=False)¶

Run worker() on things within an iterable made up of mappings.

>>> # filter items
>>> __(dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)]), dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)])
... ).worker(lambda x, y: x * y).mapping().fetch()
[2, 6, 12, 2, 6, 12]
>>> # mapping keys only
>>> __(dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)]), dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)])
... ).mapping(keys=True).fetch()
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3]
>>> # mapping values only
>>> __(dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)]), dict([(1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 4)])
... ).mapping(values=True).fetch()
[2, 3, 4, 2, 3, 4]
Parameters:
  • keys (boolean) – collect mapping keys only
  • values (boolean) – collect mapping values only
max()¶

Find maximum value within an iterable using worker() as the key function.

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(1, 2, 4).max().fetch()
4
>>> stooges = (
...    {'name': 'moe', 'age': 40},
...    {'name': 'larry', 'age': 50},
...    {'name': 'curly', 'age': 60},
... )
>>> # using worker as key function
>>> __(*stooges).worker(lambda x: x['age']).max().fetch()
{'name': 'curly', 'age': 60}
median()¶

Find median value within an iterable.

>>> __(4, 5, 7, 2, 1).median().fetch()
4
>>> __(4, 5, 7, 2, 1, 8).median().fetch()
4.5
merge()¶

Combine multiple iterables into one iterable.

>>> __(['moe', 'larry', 'curly'], [30, 40, 50], [True, False, False]).merge().fetch()
['moe', 'larry', 'curly', 30, 40, 50, True, False, False]
min()¶

Find minimum value within an iterable using worker() as the key function.

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(10, 5, 100, 2, 1000).min().fetch()
2
>>> # using worker as key function
>>> __(10, 5, 100, 2, 1000).worker(lambda x: x % 10 == 0).min().fetch()
10
minmax()¶

Find minimum and maximum values within an iterable.

>>> minmax = __(1, 2, 4).minmax().fetch()
>>> minmax.minimum
1
>>> minmax.maximum
4
Returns:namedtuple of (minimum value, maximum value).
original()¶

Restore incoming things back to initial snapshot.

>>> undone = __(1, 2, 3).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
>>> undone.original().peek()
[1, 2, 3]
params(*args, **kw)¶

Assign global positional and keyword params used when the worker is invoked.

pattern(pattern, type='parse', flags=0)¶

Compile a search pattern and use it as the worker.

>>> # using parse expression
>>> __('first test', 'second test', 'third test').pattern('first {}').filter().fetch()
'first test'
>>> # using regular expression
>>> __('first test', 'second test', 'third test').pattern('third .', type='regex').filter().fetch()
'third test'
>>> # using glob pattern
>>> __('first test', 'second test', 'third test').pattern('second*', type='glob').filter().fetch()
'second test'
Parameters:
  • pattern (string) – search pattern
  • type (string) – engine to compile pattern with. Valid options are ‘parse’, ‘re’, or ‘glob’
  • flags (integer) – regular expression flags
peek()¶

Preview current state of incoming things (wrapped with the current iterable as_type).

permutations(n)¶

Find permutations of every n things within an iterable.

>>> __(40, 50, 60).permutations(2).fetch()
[(40, 50), (40, 60), (50, 40), (50, 60), (60, 40), (60, 50)]
Parameters:n (integer) – length of things to permutate from
prepend(*things)¶

Insert things before other incoming things.

>>> __(3, 4, 5).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 3, 4, 5]
Parameters:things – incoming things
range()¶

Find length of the smallest interval that can contain every value within an iterable.

>>> __(3, 5, 7, 3, 11).range().fetch()
8
reduce(initial=None, reverse=False)¶

Reduce an iterable down to one thing using the worker.

>>> # reduce from left side
>>> __(1, 2, 3).worker(lambda x, y: x + y).reduce().fetch(),
6
>>> # reduce from left side with initial value
>>> __(1, 2, 3).worker(lambda x, y: x + y).reduce(1).fetch()
7
>>> # reduce from right side
>>> __([0, 1], [2, 3], [4, 5]).worker(lambda x, y: x + y).reduce(reverse=True).fetch()
[4, 5, 2, 3, 0, 1]
>>> # reduce from right side with initial value
>>> __([0, 1], [2, 3], [4, 5]).worker(lambda x, y: x + y).reduce(initial=[0, 0], reverse=True).fetch()
[4, 5, 2, 3, 0, 1, 0, 0]
Parameters:
  • initial – starting value
  • reverse (boolean) – reduce from the right side of an iterable
repeat(n=None, call=False)¶

Repeat either an iterable or invoke worker() n times.

>>> # repeat iterable
>>> __(40, 50, 60).repeat(3).fetch()
[(40, 50, 60), (40, 50, 60), (40, 50, 60)]
>>> def test(*args):
...    return list(args)
>>> # with worker
>>> __(40, 50, 60).worker(test).repeat(3, True).fetch()
[[40, 50, 60], [40, 50, 60], [40, 50, 60]]
Parameters:
  • n (integer) – number of times to repeat
  • call (boolean) – repeat results of invoking worker
rest()¶

Slice off everything from an iterable except the first thing.

>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).rest().fetch()
[4, 3, 2, 1]
reverse()¶

Reverse the order of things within an iterable.

>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).reverse().fetch()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
sample(n)¶

Randomly slice off n things from an iterable.

>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).sample(3).fetch()
[2, 4, 5]
Parameters:n (integer) – size of sample
shuffle()¶

Randomly sort the order of things within an iterable.

>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).shuffle().fetch()
[3, 1, 5, 4, 2]
slice(start, stop=False, step=False)¶

Slice off things from iterable.

>>> # slice from index 0 to 3
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).slice(2).fetch()
[5, 4]
>>> # slice from index 2 to 4
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).slice(2, 4).fetch()
[3, 2]
>>> # slice from index 2 to 4 with 2 steps
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).slice(2, 4, 2).fetch()
3
Parameters:
  • start (integer) – starting index of slice
  • stop (integer) – stopping index of slice
  • step (integer) – size of step in slice
snapshot()¶

Take baseline snapshot of the current state of incoming things.

sort()¶

Randomly reorder things within an iterable.

>>> # default sort
>>> __(4, 6, 65, 3, 63, 2, 4).sort().fetch()
[2, 3, 4, 4, 6, 63, 65]
>>> from math import sin
>>> # using worker as key function
>>> __(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).worker(sin).sort().fetch()
[5, 4, 6, 3, 1, 2]
stepback()¶

Restore incoming things back to baseline snapshot.

>>> undone = __(1, 2, 3).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
>>> undone.snapshot().append(1).append(2).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2]
>>> undone.stepback().peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
sum(start=0, precision=False)¶

Find total value by adding up start and everything else within an iterable together.

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(1, 2, 3).sum().fetch()
6
>>> # with a starting mumber
>>> __(1, 2, 3).sum(start=1).fetch()
7
>>> # add floating points with extended precision
>>> __(.1, .1, .1, .1, .1, .1, .1, .1).sum(precision=True).fetch()
1.0
Parameters:
  • start (integer or float) – starting number
  • precision (boolean) – add floats with extended precision
traverse(invert=False)¶

Collect nested values from each thing within an iterable matched by the worker.

>>> class stooges:
...    name = 'moe'
...    age = 40
>>> class stooge2:
...    name = 'larry'
...    age = 50
>>> class stooge3:
...    name = 'curly'
...    age = 60
...    class stooge4(object):
...        name = 'beastly'
...        age = 969
>>> # default behavior
>>> __(stooges, stooge2, stooge3).traverse().fetch()
[ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooges'), ('age', 40), ('name', 'moe')])),
ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooge2'), ('age', 50), ('name', 'larry')])),
ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooge3'), ('age', 60), ('name', 'curly')]),
OrderedDict([('age', 969), ('name', 'beastly'), ('classname', 'stooge4')]))])
>>> def test(x):
...    if x[0] == 'name':
...        return True
...    elif x[0].startswith('__'):
...        return True
...    return False
>>> # using worker while filtering for False values
>>> __(stooges, stooge2, stooge3).worker(test).traverse(invert=True).fetch()
[ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooges'), ('age', 40)])),
ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooge2'), ('age', 50)])),
ChainMap(OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooge3'), ('age', 60)]),
OrderedDict([('classname', 'stooge4'), ('age', 969)]))]
Parameters:invert (boolean) – select things that the worker evaluates as False rather than True
undo(snapshot=0)¶

Restore incoming things to a previous state.

>>> undone = __(1, 2, 3).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
>>> # undo back one step
>>> undone.append(1).undo().peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
>>> # undo back one step
>>>> undone.append(1).append(2).undo().peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3, 1]
>>> # undo back 2 steps
>>> undone.append(1).append(2).undo(2).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3, 1]
Parameters:snapshot (integer) – number of steps ago e.g. 1, 2, 3
union()¶

Find unions within a series of iterables.

>>> __([1, 2, 3], [101, 2, 1, 10], [2, 1]).union().fetch()
[1, 10, 3, 2, 101]
unique()¶

Find unique things within an iterable.

>>> # default behavior
>>> __(1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4).unique().fetch()
[1, 2, 3, 4]
>>> # using worker as key function
>>> __(1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 4).worker(round).unique().fetch()
[1, 2, 3, 4]
weave()¶

Interleave things found at the same index position in multiple iterables while reducing the multiple iterables to one iterable. >>> __([‘moe’, ‘larry’, ‘curly’], [30, 40, 50], [True, False, False]).weave().fetch() [‘moe’, 30, True, ‘larry’, 40, False, ‘curly’, 50, False]

worker(worker)¶

Assign worker.

Parameters:worker – a Python callable
zip()¶

Reduce multiple iterables to one iterable while pairing things found at the same index position within an iterable in a tuple.

>>> __(['moe', 'larry', 'curly'], [30, 40, 50], [True, False, False]).zip().fetch()
[('moe', 30, True), ('larry', 40, False), ('curly', 50, False)]
